Delayed umbilical cord clamping until at least one minute after birth (or after cessation of cord pulsation) can 
help prevent iron deficiency in neonates [131,132]. Neonates who undergo late umbilical cord clamping have 
significantly higher levels of haemoglobin compared with neonates who undergo umbilical cord clamping too 
early, and their ferritin levels remain higher until six months of age [131,132].
